elements.content: A series of novel lanthanide coordination polymers have been successfully synthesized under hydrothermal or solvothermal conditions, namely, [Eu2(2,4′-bpdc)2(OH)­(NO3)­(H2O)3] n (1), [Ln­(2,4′-bpdc)­(1,4-bdc)0.5(DMF)-(H2O)·H2O] n [Ln = Eu (2); Ln = Pr (3); Ln = Nd (4)], [Ln­(2,4′-bpdc)­(DMF)2NO3] n [Ln = Eu (5); Ln = Nd (6); Ln = Gd (7)], and [Eu­(2,4′-bpdc)­(2,4′-Hbpdc)­(H2O)] n (8), (2,4′-H2bpdc = 2,4′-biphenyldicarboxylic acid, 1,4-H2bdc = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid, and DMF = N,N′-dimethylformamide). X-ray crystallographic studies reveal that 1 features a three-dimensional (3D) framework with 45 topology. 2–4, which are isostructural and synthesized by using a mixture of 2,4′-H2bpdc and 1,4-H2bdc, exhibit two-dimensional (2D) (3,4)-connected net structures. 5–7 show 2D layered structures containing double helix chains (Δ and Λ) with 44 topology. 8 possesses a 2D layered structure containing (4,6)-connected networks, which are connected by means of infinite zigzag chains linked by 2,4′-bpdc2– and 2,4′-Hbpdc– anions. Furthermore, steady-state and time-resolved spectroscopic measurements reveal that the four Eu­(III) complexes, 1, 2, 5, and 8, exhibit remarkable red luminescence emissions with lifetimes at the millisecond scale. Complexes 4 and 6 display characteristic luminescent properties for Nd­(III) in the near-infrared region. The singlet state and the lowest triplet level of ligand 2,4′-H2bpdc were calculated on the basis of the UV–vis absorbance edges of ligand and the phosphorescence spectrum of Gd­(III) complex 7. The energy transfer mechanisms in the lanthanide polymers are described and discussed.

elements.content: Designing porous and high-dimensional metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) through self-assembly processes has mushroomed in the past decade. Among the different metal candidates, lanthanide ions are good choices to build high-dimensional MOFs and form condensed structure due to their high coordination numbers and flexible coordination environments. In addition, lanthanides have attracted special interest for its particular properties, such as gas storage, catalysis, luminescence, and magnetism behaviors. In particular, more and more attention has been focused upon luminescent active materials for organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs). Lanthanide luminescence has been applied in material sciences. For instance, europium and terbium complexes emit fluorescence in the visible spectral region and are used as sensors and as luminescent labels in fluoroimmunoassays and time-resolved microscopy. A lot of interest is also devoted to lanthanide ions emitting in the near-infrared (NIR) region because of their possible applications in long-range optical data transport. However, compared with the characteristic luminescence in the visible region, investigations on luminescent properties in the NIR region of MOFs are still in their infancy because lanthanide polymers are more difficult to prepare in contrast to d-block transition metal polymers.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Designing porous and high-dimensional metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) through self-assembly processes has mushroomed in the past decade. Among the different metal candidates, lanthanide ions are good choices to build high-dimensional MOFs and form condensed structure due to their high coordination numbers and flexible coordination environments. In addition, lanthanides have attracted special interest for its particular properties, such as gas storage, catalysis, luminescence, and magnetism behaviors. In particular, more and more attention has been focused upon luminescent active materials for organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs). Lanthanide luminescence has been applied in material sciences. For instance, europium and terbium complexes emit fluorescence in the visible spectral region and are used as sensors and as luminescent labels in fluoroimmunoassays and time-resolved microscopy. A lot of interest is also devoted to lanthanide ions emitting in the near-infrared (NIR) region because of their possible applications in long-range optical data transport. However, compared with the characteristic luminescence in the visible region, investigations on luminescent properties in the NIR region of MOFs are still in their infancy because lanthanide polymers are more difficult to prepare in contrast to d-block transition metal polymers.

elements.content: Besides, luminescent coordination polymers based on polycarboxylic ligands are also prevalent because of their various coordination modes. The addition of completely or partially deprotonated carboxylate groups on the molecules is beneficial to the formation of unusual multidimensional architectures. At the same time, polycarboxylic ligands are good agents to promote luminescence by energy transfer. Actually, several dicarboxylate mediated coordination polymers have proved to be quite successful in forming self-assembled open frameworks accommodating various guest species. Particularly, 2,4′-H2bpdc contains a biphenyl spacer with structural flexibility and conformation freedom. Certain extent and rotation of the C–C single bond between two phenyl rings could form numbers of coordination geometries of metal ions. The potential coordination sites, four oxygen atoms of two carboxylate groups, may supply anions of two different valences as compensating charge and various acidity-dependent coordination modes (Scheme ). To date, some d-block transition metal coordination polymers with 2,4′-H2bpdc ligand have been isolated; however, lanthanide complexes of 2,4′-H2bpdc acid ligand remain unexplored. Led to this interesting and challenging field, we report herein syntheses and crystal structures of a series of novel 2D layers and 3D porous carboxylic lanthanide­(III) complexes based on dicarboxylic acid as linkers and trivalent lanthanide­(III) ions (Pr, Nd, Eu, and Gd) as connectors. For complexes 2–4, secondary ligand 1,4-H2bdc is used as a colinker to tune the structure of the MOFs. The photoluminescent properties are investigated in detail. The spectra show that Nd­(III) and Eu­(III) complexes display metal-based emission properties. Besides, time-resolved spectroscopic measurements reveal that Eu­(III) complexes have lifetimes at the millisecond level.

elements.content: Solvents and starting materials were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 automatic analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum 100 FT-IR spectrometer as KBr pellets in the 4000–400 cm–1 region. The solid-state photoluminescence analyses were performed on an Edinburgh FLS920 fluorescence spectrometer in the range of 200–1400 nm. The visible and NIR detectors as well as the lifetime setup are a red-sensitive photomultiplier (type r928) and Ge detector, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Characterization Techniques

Solvents and starting materials were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 automatic analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum 100 FT-IR spectrometer as KBr pellets in the 4000-400 cm-1 region. The solid-state photoluminescence analyses were performed on an Edinburgh FLS920 fluorescence spectrometer in the range of 200-1400 nm. The visible and NIR detectors as well as the lifetime setup are a red-sensitive photomultiplier (type r928) and Ge detector, respectively.

elements.content: A mixture of 2,4′-H2bpdc (0.0242 g 0.1 mmol) and Eu­(NO3)3·5H2O (0.0856 g, 0.2 mmol) was dissolved in distilled water (8 mL). When the pH value of the mixture was adjusted to ca. 5.7 with Et3N, the solution was transferred into a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave heated at 165 °C for 3 days. After the sample was cooled to room temperature, block-shaped colorless crystals appeared. Yield: 35% (based on lanthanide metal). Elemental anal. Calcd for C28H23NO15Eu2: C, 36.66; H, 2.53; N, 1.53%. Found: C, 36.98; H, 2.70; N, 1.25%. FT-IR (KBr, cm–1): 3427 (s), 1539 (s), 1400 (s), 1182 (m), 1101 (m), 1006 (m), 846 (m), 754 (s), 667 (m), 516 (w).

elements.content: Suitable single-crystals were selected for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The data were collected on a Bruker Apex II CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo-Ka radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 ± 2 K. Data processing was accomplished with the SAINT processing program. The structures were solved by direct method and refined by full-matrix, least-squares based on F 2 using the SHELXTL 5.1 software package. The lanthanide atoms were first located, and then the oxygen, carbon, nitrogen, and hydrogen atoms in the complexes 1–8 were found in Fourier difference maps. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropical thermal parameters. The hydrogen atoms except those for water molecules were not included in the refinements. In complex 3, O2w is disordered and occupies two sites (0.284 and 0.216). Crystallographic data and structural refinements for complexes 1–8 are summarized in Table . CCDC reference numbers: 833803 for 1, 833802 for 2, 833804 for 3, 833805 for 4, 833808 for 5, 833806 for 6, 833807 for 7, and 834034 for 8.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Structure Determination

Suitable single-crystals were selected for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The data were collected on a Bruker Apex II CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo-Ka radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 ± 2 K. Data processing was accomplished with the SAINT processing program. The structures were solved by direct method and refined by full-matrix, least-squares based on F 2 using the SHELXTL 5.1 software package. The lanthanide atoms were first located, and then the oxygen, carbon, nitrogen, and hydrogen atoms in the complexes 1-8 were found in Fourier difference maps. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropical thermal parameters. The hydrogen atoms except those for water molecules were not included in the refinements. In complex 3, O2w is disordered and occupies two sites (0.284 and 0.216). Crystallographic data and structural refinements for complexes 1-8 are summarized in Table . CCDC reference numbers: 833803 for 1, 833802 for 2, 833804 for 3, 833805 for 4, 833808 for 5, 833806 for 6, 833807 for 7, and 834034 for 8.

The four types of crystals structure of complexes 1–8 were successfully synthesized by reacting 2,4′-H2bpdc (auxiliary ligand 1,4-H2bdc for 2–4) with the corresponding lanthanide nitrates at 70 or 165 °C from 3–5 days under hydro­(solvo)­thermal conditions. The reaction route of 1–8 is shown as Scheme . The conditions of the respective reactions were affected by pH value, reaction temperature, and metal–ligand ratio. Complex 1 is a novel 3D framework, whose optimal conditions are 165 °C, pH value of 5.7, and metal–ligand ratio as 2:1. It is proven that a higher temperature and bigger metal–ligand ratio are apt to permit construction of 3D architectures. Meanwhile, completely deprotonated carboxylate groups on the molecules under higher pH values possess a versatile coordination fashion, which results in 3D MOFs via linking metals and carboxylate molecules. In contrast to 1, pH values of complexes 2–8 [2–4 (at ca. 5.0) and 5–8 (at ca. 2.0)] are smaller than 1; complexes 2–8 have a lower metal–ligand ratio, and the reaction temperature of complexes 2–7 (70 °C) is lower than that of 1, all of which possess a 2D structure. The structural investigations testify that the pH value, temperature, and metal–ligand ratio cooperatively affect the formation of 3D complex 1.

Synthesis and Characterization

The four types of crystals structure of complexes 1-8 were successfully synthesized by reacting 2,4'-H2bpdc (auxiliary ligand 1,4-H2bdc for 2-4) with the corresponding lanthanide nitrates at 70 or 165 °C from 3-5 days under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions. The reaction route of 1-8 is shown as Scheme . The conditions of the respective reactions were affected by pH value, reaction temperature, and metal-ligand ratio. Complex 1 is a novel 3D framework, whose optimal conditions are 165 °C, pH value of 5.7, and metal-ligand ratio as 2:1. It is proven that a higher temperature and bigger metal-ligand ratio are apt to permit construction of 3D architectures. Meanwhile, completely deprotonated carboxylate groups on the molecules under higher pH values possess a versatile coordination fashion, which results in 3D MOFs via linking metals and carboxylate molecules. In contrast to 1, pH values of complexes 2-8 [2-4 (at ca. 5.0) and 5-8 (at ca. 2.0)] are smaller than 1; complexes 2-8 have a lower metal-ligand ratio, and the reaction temperature of complexes 2-7 (70 °C) is lower than that of 1, all of which possess a 2D structure. elements.content: The IR spectra of complexes 1–8, ligand 2,4′-H2bpdc, and 1,4-H2bdc have been measured (Figure S1 in the ). The IR spectra of 2–4 are fully identical. This indicates that the three complexes may be isostructural, which was further confirmed by X-ray diffraction analysis. As expected, it is the same with 5–7. For example, the strong and broad absorption bands in the range of 3200–3500 cm–1 are assigned as the characteristic peak of O–H vibration from the water molecules. Moreover, the appearance of bands in the 2950–2850 cm–1 regions can be attributed to the aliphatic C–H stretching vibration modes of the −CH2– group. Extensive studies have shown that the characteristic bands of the carboxylate groups in 1–8 are all in the range from 1540 to 1640 cm–1 for asymmetric stretching and 1491 to 1465 cm–1 for symmetric stretching. Compared with the intense carboxylate groups signal of 1683 cm–1 (2,4′-H2bpdc ligand) and 1689 cm–1 (1,4-H2bdc ligand), the stretching vibrations of the carboxylate groups of complexes 1–8 were bathochromically shifted and greatly reduced in intensity, which indicated the coordination interaction between the oxygen atoms of carboxylate groups and the metal ions. All the complexes 1–8 are stable in the solid state upon extended exposure to air. They have poor solubility in common organic solvents and only are slightly soluble in a very high polarity solvents, such as DMF and DMSO.

elements.content: A single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 1 is a 3D framework. The unit cell of 1 is shown in Figure ; the metal center Eu1 is eight-coordinated to two oxygen atoms (O1 and O2) of two independent 2,4′-bpdc2– anions in the 2-position, two oxygen atoms (O3 and O4) from a chelating 2,4′-bpdc2– anion in the 4′-position (coordination mode as Scheme a), one μ3-bridging oxygen atom (O9) from a NO3 – anion, one μ2-bridging oxygen atom (O11) from adjacent NO3– anion, O14 of one coordinated H2O and one terminal oxygen atom (O15) from a hydroxyl group, which exhibit a distorted dodecahedral geometry. Metal center Eu2 is nine-coordinated to two oxygen atoms (O5 and O6) of two independent 2,4′-bpdc2– anions in the 2-position, two oxygen atoms (O7 and O8) from a chelating 2,4′-bpdc2– anion in the 4′-position (coordination mode as Scheme a), one μ3-bridging oxygen atom (O9) from a NO3 – anion, two μ3-bridging oxygen atoms (O10, and O10A) from adjacent two NO3 – anions, and O12 and O13 of two coordinated H2O, exhibiting a distorted tricapped trigonal prismatic geometry (Eu–O distances: 2.305(5)–2.799(6) Å, O–Eu–O bond angles: 51.5(2)–147.7(2)o). Four Eu3+ cations are connected by sharing vertex fashion from μ2-O, μ3-O, μ3-O of NO3 – anions and μ2-O of another NO3 – anion to form a [Eu2(NO3)]2 cluster, and further are linked to construct a 1D chain structure along the [010] direction (Figure S2 in the ). Two adjacent Eu2(NO3) units in different [Eu2(NO3)] n chains are connected by two 2,4′-bpdc2– anions (2-position and 4′-position, respectively) to form an infinite double zigzag chain containing quadrangular grids with dimensions of 10.3 × 4.5 Å (atom-to-atom distances). An interesting structural feature of complex 1 is that adjacent perpendicular chains exhibit a chiral enantiomer containing left-hand (chain 1) and right-hand (chain 2) modes (Figure S3 in the ). It should be noted that the crystal structure is rare in the MOF. The nonbonding parallel chains (1) are linked by [Eu2(NO3)] n chains to form a 2D layered structure (L1) with six-membered windows along the [101] direction, as shown in Figure a. The layered structure (L2) is built up from chains (2) in the same way. L1 and L2 are perpendicular, being connected in an alternating fashion according to ABAB mode to construct a non-interpenetrating 3D lattice structure along the [001] direction. Omitting the coordinated water molecule, center metal Eu3+ cation is linked by three 2,4′-bpdc2– anions and two NO3 – anions. Therefore, Eu3+ centers are treated as 5-connected nodes. The 2,4′-bpdc2– anion is coordinated to three Eu3+ cations, which is treated as 3-connected node. NO3 – anions connect the two neighboring Eu3+ units to form an infinite framework, resulting in a novel (3,4,6)-connected net with the Schläfli symbol of {42.6}2{44.62}­{44.63.83}2, the topology shown in Figure b. The structure of complex 1 can be understood in terms of the layered structure with a (4.8.8)-net (Figure c) and a NO3 – anion. The layered structure is parallel to the bc plane and linked by the NO3 – anion to generate the 3D framework with 12-ring channels (Figure b).

Description of Crystal Structure

Complex 1 

A single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 1 is a 3D framework. The unit cell of 1 is shown in Figure ; the metal center Eu1 is eight-coordinated to two oxygen atoms (O1 and O2) of two independent 2,4'-bpdc2- anions in the 2-position, two oxygen atoms (O3 and O4) from a chelating 2,4'-bpdc2- anion in the 4'-position (coordination mode as Scheme a), one μ3-bridging oxygen atom (O9) from a NO3 - anion, one μ2-bridging oxygen atom (O11) from adjacent NO3- anion, O14 of one coordinated H2O and one terminal oxygen atom (O15) from a hydroxyl group, which exhibit a distorted dodecahedral geometry. Metal center Eu2 is nine-coordinated to two oxygen atoms (O5 and O6) of two independent 2,4'-bpdc2- anions in the 2-position, two oxygen atoms (O7 and O8) from a chelating 2,4'-bpdc2- anion in the 4'-position (coordination mode as Scheme a), one μ3-bridging oxygen atom (O9) from a NO3 - anion, two μ3-bridging oxygen atoms (O10, and O10A) from adjacent two NO3 - anions, and O12 and O13 of two coordinated H2O, exhibiting a distorted tricapped trigonal prismatic geometry (Eu-O distances: 2.305(5)-2.799(6) Å, O-Eu-O bond angles: 51.5(2)-147.7(2)o). Four Eu3+ cations are connected by sharing vertex fashion from μ2-O, μ3-O, μ3-O of NO3 - anions and μ2-O of another NO3 - anion to form a [Eu2(NO3)]2 cluster, and further are linked to construct a 1D chain structure along the [010] direction (Figure S2 in the ). Two adjacent Eu2(NO3) units in different [Eu2(NO3)] n  chains are connected by two 2,4'-bpdc2- anions (2-position and 4'-position, respectively) to form an infinite double zigzag chain containing quadrangular grids with dimensions of 10.3 × 4.5 Å (atom-to-atom distances). An interesting structural feature of complex 1 is that adjacent perpendicular chains exhibit a chiral enantiomer containing left-hand (chain 1) and right-hand (chain 2) modes (Figure S3 in the ). It should be noted that the crystal structure is rare in the MOF. The nonbonding parallel chains (1) are linked by [Eu2(NO3)] n  chains to form a 2D layered structure (L1) with six-membered windows along the [101] direction, as shown in Figure a. The layered structure (L2) is built up from chains (2) in the same way. L1 and L2 are perpendicular, being connected in an alternating fashion according to ABAB mode to construct a non-interpenetrating 3D lattice structure along the [001] direction. Omitting the coordinated water molecule, center metal Eu3+ cation is linked by three 2,4'-bpdc2- anions and two NO3 - anions. Therefore, Eu3+ centers are treated as 5-connected nodes. elements.content: X-ray analysis performed on single crystals of complexes 2–4 reveal an isostructural mode possessing one 2D layered structure with quadrilateral shaped grids. Hence, only the structure of 2 will be discussed in detail. The central Eu3+ cation is coordinated via two 2,4′-bpdc2– anions, one 1,4-bdc2– anion, one DMF, and one coordinated H2O, as shown in Figure a. Each Eu3+ cation is nine coordinated to two carboxyl oxygen atoms (O1 and O2) from the 4′-position of a chelating 2,4′-bpdc2– anion, two carboxyl oxygen atoms (O3 and O4) from the 2-position of another chelating 2,4′-bpdc2– anion (coordination mode as Scheme b), two carboxyl oxygen atoms (O6 and O7) from a chelating 1,4-bdc2– anion, one oxygen atom (O5) from a DMF molecule and O8 of one coordinated H2O molecule, forming a distorted EuO9 tetrakaidecahedron [O3, O4, O4A (x – 1/2, –y + 1/2, z – 1/2), O5 and O6 as a equatorial site]. In the molecular structure of 2, the neighboring Eu3+ cations are connected by edge sharing fashion by two three-bridging μ3-oxygen atoms [O4 and O4A (x – 1/2, –y + 1/2, z – 1/2)] to construct a dinuclear polyhedron, as shown in Figure b, which is similar to Sm2(CO2)4(H2O)2 unit with a distorted dodecahedron geometry in the [Sm­(2,4′-bpdc)­(2,4′-Hbpdc)­H2O] n . The adjacent dinuclear units are linked via two 2,4′-bpdc2– anions to form an infinite double zigzag chain containing quadrangular grids with dimensions of 9.5 × 5.4 Å (atom-to-atom distances) along the [010] direction, as shown in Figure a. These chains are linked by 1,4-bdc2– anion acting as pillar to form a 2D layered structure containing (4,4) networks with dimensions of about 15.4 × 7.7 Å (atom-to-atom distances) along the [101̅] direction, as shown in Figure b. Omitting the coordinated water molecule and DMF molecule, 2,4′-bpdc2– and 1,4-bdc2– anions are treated as 3-connected nodes and 2-connected nodes, respectively. The center metal Eu3+ cation is linked by three 2,4′-bpdc2– anions and one 1,4-bdc2– anion. Therefore, Eu3+ centers are treated as 4-connected nodes. The units construct 2D layers through the connectivity of carboxylate bridges, which results in a novel (3,4)-connected net with the Schläfli symbol of {4.82}2; the topology shown in Figure b. The free water molecules in 2 occupy 18.0% (total potential solvent volume of 889.2 Å3 out of the per unit cell volume of 4939.1 Å3) of the unit cell volume, according to a PLATON calculation. The neighboring layers show a crossbedded array along the [101] direction.

elements.content: X-ray structural determinations of complexes 5–7 exhibit an isostructural mode possessing a 2D layered structure with double helix chains. The representative structure of 5 will be described. As shown in Figure , each Eu3+ cation is eight-coordinated to two oxygen atoms (O1 and O2) of two independent 2,4′-bpdc2– anions in the 4′-position, one oxygen atoms (O4) from 2,4′-bpdc2– anion in the 2-position, one μ2-bridging oxygen atom (O3a, −x + 2, −y + 1, −z + 1) from a independent 2,4′-bpdc2– anion in the 2-position (coordination mode as Scheme i), two oxygen atoms (O7 and O8) from a chelating NO3 – anion, two oxygen atoms (O5 and O6) from two independent DMF molecules, forming a distorted EuO8 square antiprism geometry arrangement. The Eu–O bond lengths are in the range of 2.347(4)–2.535(6) Å, and the O–Eu–O bond angles range from 47.8(1) to 146.6(2)°. In the molecular structure of 5, the neighboring Eu3+ cations are connected by two μ2-oxygen atoms (O3 and O3a) of two independent 2,4′-bpdc2– anions in the 2-position to construct a dinuclear polymer. Adjacent dinuclear polymers are connected by four 2,4′-H2bpdc ligands (2-position and 4′-position, respectively) to form a 2D layered structure containing double helix chains (Δ and Λ) with 44 topology along the [100] direction, as shown in Figure a. This linking fashion is different from those reported in other complexes containing the 2,4′-H2bpdc ligand, in which the adjacent dinuclear units are connected via two 2,4′-bpdc2– anions to form an infinite double zigzag chain containing quadrangular grids. When the NO3 – anion and DMF molecule are ignored, the dinuclear site can be regarded as one node. Dinuclear polymer is connected through four neighboring 2,4′-H2bpdc ligands. The dinuclear polymer can be 4-connected building units center. The 2,4′-H2bpdc ligand connected to two neighboring dinuclear polymer, forming 2-connected nodes. Such connectivity repeats infinitely, resulting in a (4,4) networks; the topology is shown in Figure b. From the topological view, complex 5 forms 8-ring channels along the [100] direction; the pore size of the 8-rings is 16.68 × 7.72 Å.

elements.content: By modifying the metal–ligands ratio, pH value, and temperature, a new polymer 8 with a different structure was isolated. Crystal structure determination shows that complex 8 features a 2D layered structure. Each Eu3+ cation is eight coordinated to three carboxyl oxygen atoms [O4, O5A (−x + 1, −y + 1, −z), and O5B (x, y – 1, z)] from two independent 2,4′-bpdc2– anions in the 2-position, four carboxyl oxygen atoms [O3, O6, O7A (−x + 1, −y, −z), and O8] from four independent 2,4′-bpdc2– anion in the 4′-position (coordination mode as Scheme c,d), and O9 of one coordinated H2O molecule, forming a distorted dodecahedral geometry, as shown in Figure a. The neighboring Eu3+ cations are connected in edge sharing fashion from two μ3-oxygen atoms of two independent 2,4′-bpdc2– anions in the 2-position to construct a dinuclear polyhedron, as shown in Figure b. The adjacent dinuclear polyhedra are linked via two 2,4′-bpdc2– anions (the dihedral angle of biphenyl of 2,4′-bpdc2– is 53.6°) and further form an infinite zigzag chain along the [100] direction, as shown in Figure c. These chains are connected via 2,4′-Hbpdc– anion according to Scheme d (the dihedral angle of biphenyl of 2,4′-bpdc– is 77.0°) to form a 2D layered structure along the [001] direction, as shown in Figure d. Ignoring the coordinated H2O molecule, metal center Eu3+ is connected through neighboring six 2,4′-H2bpdc ligands. The metal center can be a 6-connected building unit center. The 2,4′-H2bpdc ligand in an infinite zigzag chain is connected to four neighboring metal europium centers. The 2,4′-H2bpdc ligand between two infinite zigzag chains connected to two neighboring metal europium centers is regarded as 4-connected or 2-connected nodes. Such connectivity repeats infinitely, resulting in a novel (4,6)-connection, the topology shown in Figure e. From the topological view, complex 8 forms 8-ring channels along the [001] direction; the pore size of the 8-rings is 12.54 × 9.05 Å.

elements.content: The lanthanide coordination polymers have shown good luminescence properties in terms of their high color purity. Hence, we investigated the ligand-assisted photoluminescence properties of powder samples of the lanthanide complexes at ambient temperature. Complexes 1, 2, 5, and 8 exhibit characteristic emission of Eu­(III) ions in the visible region. Complexes 4 and 6 show characteristic emission of Nd­(III) ions in the NIR region. For complex 3, no emission band in near-IR region was found. The luminescence data are given in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

The lanthanide coordination polymers have shown good luminescence properties in terms of their high color purity. Hence, we investigated the ligand-assisted photoluminescence properties of powder samples of the lanthanide complexes at ambient temperature. Complexes 1, 2, 5, and 8 exhibit characteristic emission of Eu(III) ions in the visible region. Complexes 4 and 6 show characteristic emission of Nd(III) ions in the NIR region. For complex 3, no emission band in near-IR region was found. The luminescence data are given in Table .

elements.content:
Luminescence Data for Complexes <bold>1</bold>–<bold>8</bold> <xref rid="t2fn1"></xref> complexes excitation [nm] emission [λmax, nm] decay lifetime [μs] conditions 1 305 588, 609, 652, 700 1295.42 solid, 298 K 2 395 591, 615, 650, 697 371.02 solid, 298 K 4 350 900, 1056, 1330 1.93 solid, 298 K 5 395 592, 613, 652, 699 1271.00 solid, 298 K 6 357 913, 1050, 1367 7.17 solid, 298 K 7 387 499 109.10 solid, 77 K 8 314 587, 611, 652, 699 528.17 solid, 298 K

Emission of 3 not determined.

Complexes 1, 2, 5, and 8 yield bright red luminescence in the solid state when irradiated by UV light (254 or 365 nm). Under excitation at 305, 395, 395, and 314 nm, respectively, the fluorescent spectra of complexes 1, 2, 5, and 8 are impressive as the transitions to the ground-state manifold from the emitting 5D0 level, exhibiting four intense characteristic emission bands in the visible region (Figure ). These emission bands of 1, 2, 5, and 8 at ca. 590, 613, 652, and 700 nm are assigned to the 5D0 → 7FJ (J = 1, 2, 3, and 4) transitions. It is worthy to note that these characteristic emission bands indicate that the ligand-to-metal energy transfer is moderately efficient under the experimental conditions used. Moreover, the intensity of the hypersensitive transition, 5D0 → 7F2, is much larger than that of the 5D0 → 7 F1 transition in these four complexes, indicating a highly polarizable chemical environment around the Eu­(III) ion. The intensity ratio of 5D0 →7 F2 transition (electric dipole transition) to 5D0 → 7F1 transition (magnetic dipole transition) of 1, 2, 5, and 8 are 3.8, 3.2, 4.8, and 4.5, respectively. These results can most likely ascribed the non-centrosymmetric coordination environment around the Eu centers. Besides, in view of the low sensitivity of the visible detectors, the transitions to upper 7FJ (J = 5, 6) levels at ca. 750 and 810 nm (presents only 5–10% of the total intensity) are too tricky to measure.

elements.content: When excited at 350 and 375 nm, 4 and 6 give rise to three bands within the 880–1367 nm range (Figure ). The main emission bands occur between 1022 and 1096 nm (4F3/2 → 4I11/2), with a maximum at 1055 nm for 4 (1050 nm for 6). Simultaneously, the two other bands appear between 880 and 1010 nm (4F3/2 → 4I9/2) and 1281–1361 nm (4F3/2 → 4I13/2), respectively. The 4F3/2 → 4I9/2 emission of 4 and 6 presents some splitting, which is mainly attributed to “crystal-filed effects” of Nd­(III) ion in a C 1 symmetry. NIR-emitting lanthanides have a comparatively small energy gap between these two states, which markedly extends the available absorption envelope into the visible region and consequent range of sensitizing chromophores that can be employed.

elements.content: To elucidate the energy transfer processes of complex 5, the energy levels of the relevant electronic states of the ligand have been investigated. The singlet state (S1) energy level was estimated by referring to wavelengths of UV–vis absorbance edges of ligand. The corresponding gadolinium complex was usually selected as a model complex for the determination of the lowest triplet state (T1) energies of the organic ligands owing to their high phosphorescence-fluorescence ratio compared to those of the other Ln­(III) complexes and Gd­(III) is able to sensitize the phosphorescence emission of ligand. To test this assignment of absorbance edges and the emission bands, we have carried out UV–vis absorbance and photoluminescence studies on 2,4′-H2bpdc. The singlet energy level (S1) of the ligand is 28571 cm–1 (350 nm) ((Figure S4 in the ). The datum of the triplet excited state T1 of 2,4′-H2bpdc (20040 cm–1) was calculated by the low-temperature (77 K) phosphorescence spectrum of the Gd­(III) complex 7 (Figure ). According to Reinhoudt’s empirical rule, the intersystem crossing (ISC) process becomes effective when ΔE is at least 5000 cm–1. The energy gap ΔE (S1 – T1) for the ligand is 8531 cm–1. Thus, the ISC is effective in this ligand. It is necessary that a suitable energy gap exists between the ligand-centered triplet state and the lanthanide ion emissive states. Latva’s empirical rule states that an optimal ligand-to-metal energy transfer process for Ln­(III) needs [ΔE = E(T1) – E(5DJ)] 2500 – 4000 cm–1 for Eu­(III). The experimentally observed (T1) energy level of the ligand is 2740 cm–1 higher than the 5D0 level [E(5D0) = 17300 cm–1] (Figure ). Hence, 2,4′-H2bpdc makes a very efficient ligand to sensitize Eu­(III) emission. The ligand-centered emission of the triplet state has completely disappeared in europium complex 5, which shows that the efficient energy transfer could happen from the triplet state to the resonance level of a lanthanide ion.

elements.content: In addition to the steady-state emission, we also performed time-resolved measurements by using the time-correlated single photon counting (TCSPC) technique. The decay curves are well fitted into a monoexponential function: I 0 = I + A 1 exp­(−t/τ1 ), where I and I 0 are the luminescent intensities at time t = t and t = 0, respectively, and τ1 is defined as the luminescent lifetime. The best fit of the experimental luminescence intensities to the above equation led to the following luminescence lifetimes as shown in Table . Remarkably, the europium complexes 1, 2, 5, and 8 show the typical phosphorescence (the average lifetime for phosphorescence ranges from 10–4 to 104 s). It should be noted that only a few coordination polymers have been reported to exhibit a millisecond time scale. The lifetime trend of europium complexes 1, 2, 5, and 8 series is found to follow the order: 2 < 8 < 5 < 1. Among the Eu­(III) complexes, 1 has the longest lifetime on account of the 3D condensed structure, which suggests that the lanthanide ions in 1 are well shielded from nonradiative deactivations. For complex 2, the auxiliary ligand 1,4-H2bdc is introduced, which reduces π conjugation of the system in contrast to biphenyl spacer of free 2,4′-H2bpdc ligand. Thus, the levels of luminescence lifetimes of 2 level are shorter than those of pure MOF 1. The medial values of lifetimes, for the other two Eu­(III) complexes 5 and 8, are within the same range as those published recently.

elements.content: In summary, the hydro­(solvo)­thermal syntheses, crystal structures, and luminescent properties of eight novel lanthanide­(III) MOFs with 2,4′-biphenyldicarboxylic acid and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid have been described. Their structures can be influenced by pH value, reaction temperature, metal–ligand ratio, and the coordination modes of the ligand. This synthetic technique also allows us to design new types of lanthanide complexes with novel crystal structures and luminescent properties. Neodymium, europium, and gadolinium complexes exhibit characteristic luminescent properties with near-infrared, red, and purple-blue emissions, respectively. Our studies show that complexes 1, 2, 5, and 8 have the lifetimes at millisecond levels and thus may become promising candidates for red luminescent materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, the hydro(solvo)thermal syntheses, crystal structures, and luminescent properties of eight novel lanthanide(III) MOFs with 2,4'-biphenyldicarboxylic acid and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid have been described. Their structures can be influenced by pH value, reaction temperature, metal-ligand ratio, and the coordination modes of the ligand. This synthetic technique also allows us to design new types of lanthanide complexes with novel crystal structures and luminescent properties. Neodymium, europium, and gadolinium complexes exhibit characteristic luminescent properties with near-infrared, red, and purple-blue emissions, respectively. Our studies show that complexes 1, 2, 5, and 8 have the lifetimes at millisecond levels and thus may become promising candidates for red luminescent materials.
